title: 108_hr1780
content: The text introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code excluding net capital gain of taxpayers other than corporations. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code excludes the net capital gain of taxpayers other than corporations. Amendments are made to various sections to align with this change. The amendments exclude net capital gain of taxpayers other than corporations and apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Additionally, a new section in the Internal Revenue Code excludes dividends and interest received by individuals. SEC. 116 of the Internal Revenue Code excludes dividends and interest received by individuals, with certain exceptions for dividends from tax-exempt corporations. For capital gain dividends treatment, refer to sections 854(a) and 857(c). Nonresident aliens are ineligible for exclusion under certain conditions. Dividends from employee stock ownership plans are not covered. Conforming amendments include changes to section 32(c)(5) regarding interest and dividends received. The text chunk discusses amendments related to interest and dividends excluded from gross income under section 116 in the tax code. Amendments include changes to sections 32(i)(2)(A) and 86(b)(2)(B) to account for exempt interest and dividends. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to coordinate with section 116, which excludes interest and dividends from gross income. This includes changes to sections 135(d)(4), 265(a)(2), and 584(c) to account for the exclusion of interest on obligations or shares. Amendments to the tax code align with section 116, excluding dividends and interest from gross income. Sections 643, 854(a), and 857(c) are modified to account for this exclusion. Amendments to the tax code exempt capital gain dividends from real estate investment trusts from being considered as dividends for individuals and corporations. The amendments made by this section exclude dividends and interest received by individuals from taxation, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Additionally, the 1993 income tax increase on social security benefits is repealed. The amendment to section 86 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 restores the formula for including Social Security benefits in gross income for taxpayers. It repeals the adjusted base amount and defines the base amount based on filing status. The amendment to section 86 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 modifies the treatment of Social Security benefits for taxpayers based on filing status. It adjusts the percentage of benefits included in gross income for married taxpayers who do not file jointly and do not live apart from their spouse. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to other sections of the Code and the Social Security Amendments of 1983. The changes include adjustments to the percentage of benefits included in gross income for married taxpayers who do not file jointly and do not live apart from their spouse. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to other sections of the Code and the Social Security Amendments of 1983. Effective dates for these amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002, with specific dates for benefits paid after December 31, 2002. Amounts equal to the reduction in revenues to the Treasury are appropriated to the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund to replicate transfers that would have occurred if the Act had not been enacted. The Secretary of the Treasury or delegate must annually report to the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee on the transfers made under this section.
